text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

Incorporated guidance from Interim Guidance AP-08-0720-0012, Uploading all Final Appeals Case Memorandums on ACDS is Mandatory for all Cases, dated July 20, 2020. This IG makes it mandatory for all Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs), who prepare ACMs, to upload all ﬁnal ACMs and Forms 5402, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, into the Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS).
) Incorporated guidance from Interim Guidance AP-
, Uploading all Final Appeals Case Memorandums on ACDS is Mandatory for all Cases, dated July

) Made editorial changes throughout to update links and correct spelling, punctuation and spacing. (

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 8.6.2, Appeals Case Memo (ACM) Procedures, dated 08-17-2017, and incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0720-0012, Uploading all Final Appeals Case Memorandums on ACDS is Mandatory for all Cases, dated July 20, 2020.

) Purpose: This IRM section provides detailed instructions for Appeals Employees (ATEs), on how to prepare an Appeals Case Memo (ACM). and (
) Audience: Appeals. (
) Policy Owner: Chief, Appeals. (
) Program Owner: Director, Case and Operations Support. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this (

) Appeals is the only administrative function of the Service with authority to consider settlements of tax controversies and has the primary responsibility resolve these disputes without litigation to the maximum extent possible. Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases, holding conferences, and ing settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers, IRC
). See also Pub
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights. (
) Public Law
, also known as the Plain Writing Act of

, that Government documents issued to the public must be written clearly and for other purposes. The term ‘‘plain writing’’ means writing that is clear, concise, well-organized, and follows other best practices appropriate to the subject or ﬁeld and intended audience. (

) The Director of Case Operations and Support is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to the ﬁeld, training, establishing and taining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams, operational reviews, providing information on case work ﬂow, identifying and resolving issues that impact Appeals stakeholders, coordinating advisory boards, providing coordinated and complete Appeals responses to GAO and TIGTA reports, overseeing the Appeals Internal Management Document program, developing and implementing alternative dispute resolution and providing oversight and program direction for the Appeals Quality Mea- surement System (AQMS) and case support functions. (
) This IRM section focuses on providing procedures for preparing Appeals Memorandums that are clear, concise, well-organized, and adequately the basis for the decision made. (
) Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQA) provides trends and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

) Appeals is the only administrative function of the Service with authority to consider settlements of tax controversies and has the primary responsibility to resolve these disputes without litigation to the maximum extent possible. Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases, holding conferences, and ing settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers, IRC
). See also Pub

, establishes that Government documents issued to the public must be written clearly and for other purposes. The term ‘‘plain writing’’ means writing that is clear, concise, well-organized, and follows other best practices appropriate to the subject or ﬁeld and intended audience. (

) The Director of Case Operations and Support is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to the ﬁeld, training, establishing and main- taining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams, conducting operational reviews, providing information on case work ﬂow, identifying and resolving issues that impact Appeals stakeholders, coordinating advisory boards, providing coordinated and complete Appeals responses to GAO and TIGTA reports, overseeing the Appeals Internal Management Document program, developing and implementing alternative dispute resolution programs, and providing oversight and program direction for the Appeals Quality Mea- surement System (AQMS) and case support functions. surement System (AQMS) and case support functions.

) This section explains how Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs), (as IRM
) prepare an Appeals Case Memo (ACM). Also, see the for other guidance on preparing ACMs and/or ACM attachments: • IRM

) The ACM is a report the ATE prepares to adequately explain and support basis on which a work unit is disposed. Every Appeals work unit requires ACM. The exception to this general rule is where disposition of the case be explained in a brief comment. See IRM
) Prepare the ACM with the focus on the primary reader. See IRM (
) Include the following in the ACM: a. Information that explains and supports the ATE’s basis for b. Any follow up action for Compliance personnel. See IRM
c. Information for Counsel to prepare for trial and to evaluate the proposal. See IRM
d. Discussion (as deemed appropriate) about material received during Appeals’ consideration. See IRM
) Prepare the ACM, using “plain language.” See IRM

) Separately frame each new issue raised by the taxpayer, and don’t offset issue against a Compliance raised issue - unless there’s an obvious and pelling reason to do so. (e.g. Appeals allows depreciation on the an asset which is expensed by the taxpayer and fully disallowed by IRS pliance.) (
) Prepare consolidated ACMs covering the key case and all related cases avoid unnecessary duplication of information. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Appeals Case Memo Procedures 8.6.2

summary and brief analysis of what the taxpayer and examiner did or said. Brieﬂy state the rationale for the recommendation. Include the litigating hazards facing the government and how they affect the settlement. (

) Brief Background: This is an optional section, used to describe anything general to the entire issue. Think of this section as a way to give the reader just the basic facts. Save other facts for later, and put them where the reader needs them. This section doesn’t include controversial statements. It simply says enough to give context for what follows.
Jay Bird’s case separately; therefore, it isn’t associated with the tion’s case. (

) Discussion and Analysis: This is the main section for a detailed discussion the issue. Along with the “Schedule of Adjustments” and the initial framing of the issue, this section also serves as a rough draft ACM. Make this section clear and concise by providing a blueprint or outline of the discussion to In a complex issue discussion, good structure is essential. (

) My Evaluation: This section serves as a recap of the relevant factors and weight assigned to each. This analysis clearly illustrates the settlement rationale and is particularly important on complex issues and those with hazards of litigation settlements. (

) The ACM is the ATE’s summary of the issue(s) and recommended It should persuade the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) that the ATE appropri- ately considered and analyzed all important facts, arguments, and law. However, the ACM is a ﬂexible document. Depending on whether the issues are agreed or unagreed, simple or complex, your ACM can take a number formats. (
) The following are four ways to communicate the results of a case:
(03-16-2015) Types of Appeals Case Memos (ACMs)
8.6 Conference and Settlement Practices

page 4 8.6 Conference and Settlement Practices Document Description Form 5402, Appeals Transmittal and Case This form is part of all ACMs, and sometimes is all Memo that’s needed. Write the case explanation in the “Remarks and/or ACM” section for very simple cases, or when the taxpayer concedes in full. See IRM 8.6.2.3.2. Schedule of Adjustments This schedule is part of all ACMs, when just using a Form 5402 isn’t enough. Think of it as a summary. Use brief phrases to list the issues, and use columns to show the following: a. the “Examiner’s Adjustment”, b. “Appeals Change to Adjustment”, c. “Appeals Adjustment” When a narrative isn’t needed, the “Schedule of Adjustments” (combined with Form 5402) is the entire ACM. See IRM 8.6.2.4. Schedule of Adjustments with a Brief Narrative Sometimes a simple explanation is needed, along with the “Schedule of Adjustments”. See IRM 8.6.2.5. Schedule of Adjustments with a Longer A longer narrative might be necessary if the case Narrative is unagreed, involves a hazards settlement, or contains complex legal or factual issues. The longer narrative has quite a bit of ﬂexibility. It could include four major sections; but only the ﬁrst one (Summary and Recommendation) is required. The longer narrative tells the full story of an issue. See IRM 8.6.2.6. (3) For Collection-sourced work units, consider using the following documents to

) “Plain language” writing has widespread acceptance, and it should be used in all Appeals writings. If a document is prepared for use by the public, the Plain to “Plain Writing Act of

requires federal agencies to prepare written Writing that’s clear, concise, and well-organized. This “Act” also requires employees follow other “best practices” appropriate to the subject, ﬁeld, and intended audience. See Public Law

requires federal agencies to prepare written communication that’s clear, concise, and well-organized. This “Act” also requires employees to follow other “best practices” appropriate to the subject, ﬁeld, and intended audience. See Public Law
Appeals Case Memo Procedures 8.6.2
A spoken style
using ordinary words, personal pronouns, active voice, contractions, a variety of punctuation, and relatively short sentences. A clear organization
starting with the main point. An obvious layout
using short paragraphs, headings, and bullet lists.
See the following examples of conversational style writing:
Consider the intended audience when preparing the ACM or ACM attachment. Tailor the discussion to the primary reader’s needs.
For an ACM, the primary reader is the Appeals Team Manager (ATM). For an ACM attachment to a Determination letter or Decision letter, the taxpayer and ATM are the primary readers.
8.6 Conference and Settlement Practices
There could be important secondary readers, but the ACM’s focus must remain with the primary reader(s). See below for examples of secondary readers.
Reason for Review of ACM

Counsel reviews the ACM for docketed cases forwarded for trial prepara- tion, cases requiring approval to include the civil fraud penalty in a notice of deﬁciency, and for Appeals’ concession of the civil fraud penalty in certain situations. Consider providing additional information that would be helpful to Counsel. See IRM
AQMS employees review ACMs and ACM attachments for selected cases to determine if the report adequately supports the case conclusion. See IRM 8.1.7, AQMS Purpose and Guidelines.

Consciously strive to keep the “main point” in front of the reader. It’s have the main message up front and to provide breaks in the text that out each new main message. Keep the message impossible to overlook. The prescribed format for helps emphasize the main points. A “good layout” shows the reader “good organization.” Consider labeling headings or topics and use white space between. The importance of white space and simplicity shouldn’t be underrated. When used make the written report easier for the reader to understand while text ﬂow. Draw the readers’ attention to information they need to know, and using the following techniques:
Use informative headings
Use bulleted, alphabetical, or numerical lists
Use short paragraphs
Vary the alignment of the text
Left, right, and center aligning result in different effects on a page
Note: The ATE might decide to include headings under a lengthy ACM such as the Discussion and Analysis section. See IRM 8.6.2.6.3.

Graphic designers use the “dollar bill rule.” The rule says that if a block of text is larger than the size of a dollar bill, it might be too big. At that size, it appears intimidating to the reader and could take a lot of time to read and digest the information.
Memo Procedures

) ACDS is a computerized system used to control and track cases throughout the appeal process. It consists of several subsystems, including “APGolf” (Appeals Generator of Letters and Forms). APGolf is a compilation of computer-generated letters and forms, including a variety of customized
, used primarily by Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs). (
) Employees can use other ACDS subsystems, such as “CASES” or the Activity Record & Automated Timekeeping System (CARATS), to add or change source information used by APGolf. See IRM
, Appeals ized Database System (ACDS) for guidance on “CASES” data entries for validating the accuracy of these ﬁelds. (
) The “Customized Form

” was designed to... a. Address Appeals’ needs for data accuracy; b. Provide more comprehensive case closing instructions for the Account and Processing Support (APS) employee; and c. Capture case resolution reasons and other feedback information to provide to the operating divisions. (
) There are several variations of the customized Form

for differing and categories of cases considered in Appeals. The form is a tool that nates much of the guesswork previously involved in preparing the form. variation is programmed with up-to-date information presented in easy to drop-down menus and lists with boxes to check. (
) The ATE must complete the customized Form
on APGolf, so a non- customized Form
isn’t acceptable. See IRM
, Accessing the Customized Form
) For most cases, the ATE prepares the customized Form
However, an APS employee might complete a customized Form
for a dismissed For more information, see IRM
, Dismissed for Lack of Case Closing, Other Than a Premature Petition or CDP NOD. (
) Appeals employees must do the following: a. Prepare and submit a customized Form
with every completed (agreed or unagreed); b. Prepare and submit a customized Form
to return a premature referral where Appeals releases jurisdiction of the case. Note: The ATE must select a “Premature Referral Reason” on the tomized Form
The employee could use Form
, Division Feedback Report and Transmittal Memorandum in to the Customized Form

doesn’t replace Form

is complete for each case. This includes the completion of required ﬁelds, where the APGolf program forces the Appeals employee to make an entry. (

) After opening the form, conduct a data accuracy check of all information matically loaded into the form. “Type codes” and “feature codes” are Follow established procedures for correcting errors in the data. Data is an important component of the customized Form
Make all updates through CARATS or the Validation Tracking System; otherwise, request that APS make the update or correction. See IRM
, Appeals Inventory Validation Process. All data errors must be corrected before preparing and submitting the ﬁnal Form
Note: Data errors or missing data may cause an incorrect variation of the Form
to open. (

input screen for one-time use in generating Form

, but changes to pre-populated data from a source ﬁeld on ACDS, such as CASES or CARATS, can’t be saved from the input screen. You must source ﬁeld data from the source ﬁeld, such as directly from CARATS or the Validation Tracking System, or through an APS update request. For conve- nience, the data ﬁeld pre-populated from a source ﬁeld in ACDS is “colored yellow” on the Form
input screen. “White data ﬁelds” on the Form
input screen are populated by the user input. The information in “white ﬁelds” is saved and used to pre-populate subsequent Forms

in Word. If you need to make changes or you must edit subsequent forms from the input page. Appeals Case Memo Procedures 8.6.2 page 9 Feature Description ATE “Sign” Checkbox The ATE “Sign” checkbox is located on the Form 5402 input page next to “Sign/Date”. If the ATE “Sign” checkbox is checked, when the user clicks the “Save/Form” button : 1. The ATE’s signature block on the generated Form 5402 will show /s/ before the ATE’s typed name; and 2. The generated Form 5402 PDF will automati- cally save to the case as a case ﬁle attachment. Note: When an ATE uploads an electronic signed Form 5402 and/or ﬁnal ACM to ACDS, the ATE is no longer required to include paper copies of these documents in the case ﬁle. See IRM 8.24.1 for information on the Paperless CAP Process. Caution: If a user re-enters the Form 5402 input page, the user must again check the box to “sign” and “save” the latest form as a case ﬁle attachment. Delete any unused Form 5402 case ﬁle attachments. Data Capture The customized Form 5402 captures data entered and saved on the Form 5402 input page. The next time the ATE accesses the Form 5402, the data is pre-populated with information the user previously entered on this page - unless the data is populated from a source ﬁeld on ACDS such as “CASES” or “CARATS”. See IRM 8.6.2.3 (2). Mandatory Fields Programming validity checks require entries in certain mandatory ﬁelds on the customized Form 5402 input page - depending upon the work unit type, and Form 5402 won’t generate until all mandatory ﬁelds are entered. Multiple mandatory ﬁelds may be required - depending upon the type of customized Form 5402. Pop-up alerts and the Form 5402 instructions provide information on which ﬁelds are mandatory for each customized Form 5402. (9) ATEs can automatically “save” Form 5402 PDF case ﬁle attachments to ACDS

Conference and Settlement

page 10 8.6 Conference and Settlement Practices Feature Description File Name The Form PDF case ﬁle attachment is saved with a ﬁle name format that identiﬁes the following: 1. The month, day, and year the ﬁle was saved; 2. The hour, minutes, and seconds the ﬁle was saved in the ACDS ﬁle server’s time zone; 3. The ACDS User ID of the person who attached the form; 4. All or part of the taxpayer’s name; and 5. The 10-digit case work unit number.
The Form PDF case ﬁle attachment is saved with a ﬁle name format that identiﬁes the following:
The month, day, and year the ﬁle was saved;
The hour, minutes, and seconds the ﬁle was saved in the ACDS ﬁle server’s time zone;
The ACDS User ID of the person who attached the form;
All or part of the taxpayer’s name; and
The
-digit case work unit number.
Sometimes all comments and rationale about the case could ﬁt into the “Remarks” section of the Form
In these instances, the Form
serves as the entire ACM. In the three examples described below (not all-inclusive), Form
alone is sufficient; no Schedule of Adjustments is needed. IRM
) describes when to use the Schedule of Adjustments with Form

Example: The taxpayer previously provided receipts to the Examiner, which were not allowed because (insert reason). The taxpayer submitted the same documents to the AO. The AO considered and determined the receipts were allowable and the taxpayer was entitled to the deduction because (insert reason). . The AO conceded the issue in full.
Always use Form 5402 to alert the ATM and/or APS employee of signiﬁcant items in the case that must be promptly addressed. “Alerts” could include the

For cases worked outside the Appeals Team Case Leader (ATCL) Operations and the Issue Management System (IMS), the Appeals Team Managers (ATM) will forward ACMs and Form 5402 via encrypted E-mail to a centralized point of contact within LB&I and to the LB&I Team Manager. The ATM will do the following:
Send the ACM and Form

feedback via encrypted E-mail to the Outlook mailbox at lbi.acm.distribution@irs.gov and to the LB&I Team Manager; Include in the email subject line the Appeals Work Unit Number assigned to the case; Forward the feedback within
business days of case closing; and Document the case activity record that the feedback was timely sent to LB&I.

) Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) will upload their ﬁnal ACM/
into Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) for all cases. ATEs who work cases in other systems, for example, IMS, will also upload their ﬁnal ACMs/
s in ACDS. (

) When uploading the ACM, ATEs will name the ﬁle using the format “WUNO- XXXXXXXXXX-ACM” (substituting the case’s actual work unit for the Xs). format will ensure proper association with the case ﬁle and make clear that work unit number (WUNO) originated with Appeals. (
) Only the ﬁnal version of the ACM will be maintained on ACDS. Prior of the ACM, if previously uploaded, must be removed. (
) When an ATE uploads an electronic signed Form

and/or ﬁnal ACM to ACDS, the ATE is no longer required to include paper copies of these documents in the case ﬁle. Note: In the event that an ACM addresses more than one WUNO, the ATE must upload the ﬁnal ACM to each case record using the naming convention described above. (
) Account and Processing Support (APS) will electronically transmit Forms and ACMs to the originating functions and otherwise follow the current guidance speciﬁed in Appeals IRM
, Closing Procedures.

8.6.2.3.5 (07-26-2022) 5402 and ACM Case Closing Procedures
8.6 Conference and Settlement Practices
Occasionally the Schedule of Adjustments, combined with Form 5402, is the entire ACM when everything is explained with ACM codes. See IRM 8.6.2.4.7.
List issues in an order that makes sense for the case. For example, start with the most signiﬁcant issue, or group related issues.
Speciﬁcally identify and list the issue(s) on the Schedule of Adjustments as illustrated below and in the example at IRM 8.6.2.4.5 (4).

Don’t use an ACM Code when the issue is settled based on hazards, new issues are raised (other than computational or automatic adjustments), or if the substantiation is oral testimony. If either situation applies, a narrative explana
tion is necessary.
Note: See IRM
) for an example of ACM codes used in a Schedule of Adjustments for Issue #

In this example, both codes A and D were used to reﬂect that there were automatic or computational adjustments that repre- sented only part of the adjustment. For the remaining portion, the taxpayer fully conceded. (
) Consider the guidance throughout IRM
to determine whether it’s accept- able to use an ACM code, especially in regards for ACM Code C. (

) A brief narrative is appropriate for any issue that doesn’t require a lengthy ex- planation and an ACM code doesn’t apply. Sometimes simple explanations are needed in addition to a Schedule of Adjustments. In that case, use a brief narrative available on APGolf. An unagreed case or a “hazards” settlement will almost always require a longer narrative. (
) Don’t use a brief narrative for:
Conference and Settlement • A case requiring Joint Committee review; or • A return preparer penalty case going to the Office of Professional sponsibility. (
) The narrative should be brief, yet it needs to include: • The taxpayer’s position; • The examiner’s position; and • The rationale for the settlement. (

) Include references to supporting workpapers, and identify workpaper number(s) to support the narrative. The administrative ﬁle should contain necessary information to support the conclusion. Don’t increase the volume content of workpapers to compensate for the brevity of the narrative. (
) Consider using Form
, Appeals Offer in Compromise Memorandum Form
, Income and Expense/Asset Equity Calculation Table to limit written analysis. See IRM

) Sometimes a brief narrative isn’t enough to cover all of the details. This shows how to write a longer narrative. The longer narrative may have as a Longer as four sections: a. Summary and Recommendation - Required b. Brief Background - Use only when necessary c. Discussion and Analysis - Use only when necessary d. My Evaluation - Use only when necessary (
) The Summary and Recommendation is the ﬁrst section of the narrative required in all ACMs. See IRM

) for an exception. It brieﬂy and rizes the issue and the recommendation. It’s important to say enough to in the all the most important matters, yet still be concise enough that the reader Case Memo doesn’t feel bogged down in details. (

) If the issue is simple, this section may be all that’s needed. Include a and brief analysis of what the taxpayer and examiner did or said. Also, state the rationale for your recommendation. Include the “hazards of facing the government and how they affect the settlement. (

) Frame the issue as a question to help you focus your discussion. You don’t always have to answer “Yes” or “No.” Sometimes your answer may be and Your qualiﬁed. But in any case, before you start the discussion, give your reader in the answer. Correctly framing the issue sets up the discussion that follows. Case Memo are some examples: Answer

A: Yes-the government should concede the issue.
Q: Did SB Corporation ﬁle a timely Subchapter S election for 2009?

This is an optional section used to describe anything general to the entire issue. Think of this section as a way to give your reader just the basic facts. Save other facts for later, and put them where the reader needs them. Notice that there’s nothing controversial in the section. It simply says enough to give context for what follows.
(03-16-2015) “Brief Background” Section of the Appeals Case Memo (ACM)

John Sample and Jay Bird incorporated under the name SB Corporation. Each shareholder owned 50% of the corporation, and SB Corporation is in the business of veterinary medicine. The examiner is completing Jay Bird’s case separately; therefore, it isn’t associated with this ﬁle in

This is your main discussion, so it needs a clear structure. Also, this ACM section contains the most detail. This section gives the essence of both sides’ contentions, sets out new mation provided at the conference, and analyzes the law and applicable law arguments. Clearly present each main point. In this way, you’ll have a blueprint for your discussion. Present the discussion in an order that’s best suited for the issue. Consider following methods: a. Start with the taxpayer’s position - if the taxpayer has speciﬁc able arguments. Example: The taxpayer’s husband contends that he paid his wife and she performed the work of an employee. b. Begin with a brief paraphrase of the law - if the taxpayer doesn’t have speciﬁc arguments. Example: According to Treasury Reg. section
, for an be timely ﬁled for a tax year, a completed Form
must ﬁled by March
th of the year. All shareholders of the tion (at the time of the election) must consent to the
The taxpayer’s husband contends that he paid his wife wages and she performed the work of an employee.

) If the examiner and the taxpayer have presented case law arguments, distin- guish the citations and compare them and their applicability to the facts of the issue. If you need to analyze an issue or point of law in depth, give your analysis completely - but without unnecessary verbiage. (
) Distinguish alleged facts from veriﬁed or accepted facts. (
) Use dates, if important, when listing events.
8.6 Conference and Settlement Practices
Note: This helps the Counsel attorney - both in the discovery process and settle-
ment negotiations. (

) Discuss the various factors that you considered in arriving at your The reader should understand why your settlement is appropriate. Explain Based on steps you took in your evaluation process as follows: of Litigation a. Summarize the hazards that you identiﬁed in the discussion and b. Weigh their strengths and weakness. c. Determine the relative strengths of opposing positions. d. Convert your verbal evaluation to a percentage or numerical tion. (

) Bring together your discussion of factually or legally complicated issues in summary form. In a long discussion, the reader has seen a lot of facts or or Legally material. Therefore, you may need to do a short summary to bring the Issues back to the end result. Don’t use a summary, unless it’s needed; your memo will appear repetitive. (
) After recommending adjustments to the prior determination, the settlement computation is prepared - setting forth the resulting tax liability and the necessary underlying computations. See IRM
) for exceptions. as Part of (
) The settlement computations are attached to - and become part of - the Appeals Case Memo ministrative ﬁle. A copy is also part of the ACM. (
) The following forms are used (as needed) in settlement computations: a. Form
, Audit Statement. b. Form
, Statement-Income Tax Changes. c. Form
, Income Tax Examination Changes. d. Form
-A, Income Tax Discrepancy Adjustments. e. Form
-EZ, Income Tax Examination Changes.

tion.

for details. (

) A settlement computation isn’t required in the following situations, unless needed for other computational purposes: a. Compliance’s ﬁndings are sustained in full b. Compliance’s ﬁndings are completely reversed c. A Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency was issued - which adequately adjustments d. The determination in the Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency is “agreed in e. The only issues in the case involve exempt status, private foundation classiﬁcations, or employee plan qualiﬁcation questions (
) Ordinarily, settlement computations aren’t required in an unagreed case - but if the Government raises in its pleadings a new issue or the concedes an issue, one might be necessary. (
) For some docketed cases, Form
, Statement of Account, is prepared attached to the settlement computation. See IRM
, Preparing a Statement of Account. (
) When an Appeals settlement affects the taxpayer’s liability for other years related taxpayer’s liability not under Appeals’ jurisdiction, additional might be needed in the ACM and/or Form
See the following a. Basis adjustment - Include depreciation schedules. b. Carryback adjustments - Include schedule showing corrected use of carryback and affected years. (
) Ensure that Form
identiﬁes the settlement as one affecting other other taxpayers. (
) Review IRM
, Compliance Follow-Up Action Required on Related or Taxpayers for additional information to ensure appropriate instructions included on the ACM and Form

) When transferring a case to Counsel’s jurisdiction, a. Include conference notes in the ﬁle so Counsel is aware of activity. b. Explain the recommended settlement. c. Brieﬂy explain efforts to resolve the case where there’s been little or cooperation from the taxpayer or representative. d. Document the taxpayer’s failure to do the following: supply requested information, attend offered conferences, or cooperate in resolving the case. e. Explain any Appeals ﬁndings or observations that might be helpful to Counsel.
